original_data.question: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of persistent bleeding from his nose over the past hour. The bleeding started spontaneously. He has no history of a similar episode. He takes no medications. There is no history of abnormal bleeding in the family. His vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, he is pressing a gauze against his left nostril while hyperextending his head. The gauze is stained with blood and upon withdrawal of the gauze blood slowly drips out of his left nostrils. There is no bleeding from the right nostril. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?

options.C: Placement of an epinephrine gauze in the left nostril
options.D: Squeezing the nostrils manually for 10 minutes with the head elevated

model_response:
The patient has epistaxis. The most common cause of epistaxis in the pediatric population is idiopathic. The most common cause of epistaxis in adults is trauma. The most common site of epistaxis is the Woodruff area, which is the Little's area, or the site of the Kiesselbach plexus, which is the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Initial therapy for epistaxis includes the application of an anesthetic vasoconstrictor such as oxymetazoline. If this therapy is unsuccessful, anterior packing with a topical antibiotic ointment is the next step. If this therapy is unsuccessful, anterior nasal packing with a posterior nasal spray of a vasoconstrictor and topical antibiotic may be necessary. If this therapy is unsuccessful, the patient may require cauterization of the bleeding vessel.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Retained; never-ceasing.
A part of the upper respiratory tract. It contains the organ of SMELL. The term includes the external nose, the nasal cavity, and the PARANASAL SINUSES.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
Happening or arising without apparent external cause.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
Record and study of past events.
A coagulation disorder characterized by a tendency for excessive bleeding.
A social group consisting of parents or parent substitutes and children.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
One of the two channels of the nose, from the point where they divide to the external opening.
Marked or discolored by foreign material.
The body fluid that circulates in the vascular system (BLOOD VESSELS). Whole blood includes PLASMA and BLOOD CELLS.
To cease active participation in; remove from active use.
One of the two channels of the nose, from the point where they divide to the external opening.
